comment: In a few moves the whole picture has changed. Through the disappearance of the e-pawn, White is now plagued by the weakness of his isolated d-pawn; moreover, the open g-file will be favourable to Black. This is a familiar circumstance in the struggle for the centre. A central pawn majority lays upon its owner the responsibility of maintaining it. A pawn centre always has associated weaknesses, which remain latent so long as the centre is intact. As soon as it becomes impossible to hold the centre, the drawbacks loom larger
reasoning: The comment offers insightful analysis of the consequences of a specific move, suggesting a positional disadvantage for White.
